DOC.HEAD: Important Records Missing in Detroit Police Fund Probe
DOC.TEXT: Investigators looking into what happened to $1 million paid out of a Police Department undercover operations fund said important documents on a former deputy chief suspected of stealing from the account have vanished. The missing documents detail Kenneth Weiner's involvement with the fund, Executive Deputy Chief James Bannon said Tuesday. ``He's gone. The records are gone. ... He was last known to be the custodian'' of most of the documents, Bannon said. Police Chief William Hart has said Weiner, a former civilian deputy police chief, stole from the fund, which finances undercover operations of the narcotics division. Weiner was in charge of sensitive security work for the police from 1980 to 1986. He resigned in 1986 after an investigation into a precious-metals investments deal in which several Detroit-area investors lost several thousand dollars. Weiner has not been seen or heard from publicly since the federal and city investigations began several weeks ago. The FBI has refused to discuss the scope or any other details of its investigation into the fund. The FBI and U.S. attorney's office are trying to determine whether Weiner diverted hundreds of thousands of dollars from the fund for personal use. Bannon said a substantial number of documents were gone, including some subpoenaed under federal and city orders. He said a theft report was filed. The City Council subpoenaed financial records from 1985 to 1987, and city auditors began examining documents Tuesday. Release of the records averted a court battle between Mayor Coleman Young and the council, which had issued a subpoena demanding a chance to review the records. ``The mayor's concern all along was to protect the integrity of the grand jury process and the integrity of the secret service fund,'' said spokesman Bob Berg. Young, who initially said he never would give the documents to city auditors and the council, refused to say why he changed his mind.
